Expectation1: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation1: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I wipe the sweat from my brow as I hoist another plank of lumber onto my shoulder. The carpenter waves, impatient, waiting for me to bring the next load so he can keep working. My foreman expects me to keep the materials coming, no delays, no excuses. But my mind keeps drifting to the flyer in my lunchbox—the community center is running a free vaccine clinic this weekend, and I know how important it is to stay healthy, not just for myself but for everyone around me. I’ve also got my tax documents sorted, ready to file, doing my part as a responsible citizen. But if I leave the site, even for a short while, the work slows down, and the crew will be frustrated. If I stay, I might miss the clinic, and who knows when I’ll get another chance. The weight on my shoulders feels heavier than the lumber—pulled between the demands of my job and my duty to my community, I stand frozen, heart pounding, unsure which responsibility should come first.
